item.title: Kangaroos legend backs Broncos signing Matt Lodge to play for Australia - Fox Sports
item.description:
1. Kangaroos legend backs Broncos signing Matt Lodge to play for Australia  Fox Sports
  2. Renouf: Seibold can lead this Brisbane team to title  NRL.COM
  3. Divided over their new coach, Rabbitohs fans must get behind Wayne Bennett’s Bunnies  Daily Telegraph
  4. Tevita Pangai Jnr reveals real reason for short-term Broncos deal  Fox Sports
  5. Jason Demetriou sacked in wake of Wayne Bennett-Anthony Seibold cacohing swap  Sporting News AU
  6. View full coverage on Google News

item.title: Lodge, Pangai aim to become Blues brothers - SBS News
item.description:
Lodge, Pangai aim to become Blues brothers  SBS News

Brisbane forwards Tevita Pangai and Matt Lodge hope to earn NSW selection together in 2019 after hailing their friendship as the key to re-signing.

item.title: Controversial Broncos forward Matt Lodge picked in 23-man Emerging Blues Squad - Fox Sports
item.description:
Controversial Broncos forward Matt Lodge picked in 23-man Emerging Blues Squad  Fox Sports

Brisbane Broncos forward Matthew Lodge has been named in the 23-man Emerging Blues Squad following a strong and incident-free year for the Broncos.

item.title: Lodge sets sights on State of Origin - Mandurah Mail
item.description:
Lodge sets sights on State of Origin  Mandurah Mail

Now he has secured his NRL future, Brisbane prop Matt Lodge has set his sights on State of Origin. Lodge, 23, capped a season of redemption by re-signing ...

item.title: Fans convinced me to sign new Broncos deal, says Lodge - The Sydney Morning Herald
item.description:
Fans convinced me to sign new Broncos deal, says Lodge  The Sydney Morning Herald

Matt Lodge has signed a new two-year deal with the Broncos, thanking fans for their welcome after his controversial return to the NRL earlier this year.

item.title: Broncos re-signing Tevita Pangai Jr and Matt Lodge gives new coach Seibold some serious fire power - The Cairns Post
item.description:
Broncos re-signing Tevita Pangai Jr and Matt Lodge gives new coach Seibold some serious fire power  The Cairns Post

This week's re-signing of forwards Tevita Pangai Jr and Matt Lodge means new Broncos boss Anthony Seibold has a giant pack at his disposal in 2019 and ...

item.title: Demetriou’s departure imminent - The Australian
item.description:
Demetriou’s departure imminent  The Australian

Brisbane have announced the retention of Matt Lodge on a two-year-deal and stepped up talks to farewell assistant coach Jason Demetriou. Lodge was offered substantial money to leave the Broncos but a sense of loyalty to the club that helped him revive his career convinced him to stay. Reports of a mass exodus in the wake of Wayne Bennett’s departure are proving unfounded, unless the speculation is extended to include coaching staff, as assistant coach Jason Demetriou steps up talks over his exit. The players are going nowhere. Lodge yesterday confirmed he would remain at the Broncos for a f...

item.title: Glasby can become standout somebody - The Advertiser
item.description:
Glasby can become standout somebody  The Advertiser

Statistics, or rather the way they have been used, have come under fire this week for the so-called “vitriol” from south of the border against left-field Maroons selection Tim Glasby. The man himself admits he’s “a bit of a nobody” and most league fans wouldn’t have known what he looked like until they Googled him. That’s no slight on the guy. It doesn’t mean he won’t do the job. Plenty of players would like to enjoy the level of anonymity of Glasby. Anyone on Twitter would have seen the tweet doing the rounds about how in some circles a player with a dozen games under his belt nabbed for p...

item.title: Lodge in line for top honour - The Advertiser
item.description:
Lodge in line for top honour  The Advertiser

Lodge is one of five players who are in contention for the Intrust Super Cup’s best and fairest award, with PNG skipper Ase Boas, Easts halfback Brodie Croft, CQ rake Krys Freeman and Ipswich speedster Michael Purcell also in the race. While it will doubt going go down to the wire for the referee-voted award, the fact Lodge is a contender is a massive achievement given this year was his first season back in the game following a two-year exile. Redcliffe coach Adam Mogg, who has played a big part in getting him back to top form, said the news had come as no surprise to him. Mogg said Lodge h...

item.title: Disgraced NRL star avoids US jail time - The Advertiser
item.description:
Disgraced NRL star avoids US jail time  The Advertiser

A Manhattan judge was told on Monday that Lodge, who was allowed to remain in Australia for the sentencing, had fulfilled the requirements of a plea deal struck a year ago that involved community service in Australia and in-patient treatment for alcohol and anger management. If he had failed to comply he could have served a year’s jail in the US. With Lodge’s US legal troubles now resolved, it sets up his potential return to the NRL. Lodge, 21, who faced 25 years’ jail before the plea deal with New York prosecutors, began his night of terror at about 4am on October 16, 2015, when he harasse...

item.title: The rookie who saved the Bulldogs - The Advertiser
item.description:
The rookie who saved the Bulldogs  The Advertiser

Abbey’s departure will almost certainly get Canterbury salary cap compliant next year, meaning the NRL will register the contracts of Kieran Foran and Aaron Woods within weeks. It also quashes speculation that either Brett or Josh Morris will be squeezed out of the club. It is understood Raiders forward Clay Priest will join Canterbury as part of the deal. The Bulldogs’ blew their salary cap budget by up to $1 million after they over-estimated next year’s NRL’s salary cap. Despite this they still signed Foran and Woods to rich contracts while they enticed Cronulla half/hooker Nu Brown to th...

item.title: Redcliffe land Benji Marshall - The Advertiser
item.description:
Redcliffe land Benji Marshall  The Advertiser

Brisbane’s reserve-grade affiliates were given their 2017 player allocations on Wednesday and it has been confirmed that Marshall is assigned to the reigning minor premiers. There was a big battle for the services of the star playmaker, with Redcliffe, Ipswich and Wynnum all expressing interest late last year. Redcliffe CEO Grant Cleal did not return calls from The Courier-Mail yesterday but conceded the Dolphins had Marshall for the season ahead through a one word text: “Confirmed”. Coach Adam Mogg also did not respond to requests for comment but it is understood the club fought hard to st...

item.title: Broncos shock: Why I’m quitting rugby league - The Advertiser
item.description:
Broncos shock: Why I’m quitting rugby league  The Advertiser

Breaking a nine-month ­silence, a shattered Lodge has given up hope of being an NRL star, detailing plans to return to Sydney next year to work as a landscaper and play park football with his mates. “I’ve just had enough,” Lodge told The Sunday Mail. “I just feel like I’m going nowhere. I’m not progressing in the game.” It’s been almost two years since the NRL was rocked by an offshore scandal when Lodge, holidaying in the US, was arrested at gunpoint by New York police following a wild night out fuelled by alcohol and prescription medication. Aged 20, he will never forget the terror of a b...

item.title: Bennett bullet to Milf’s Cup dreams - The Advertiser
item.description:
Bennett bullet to Milf’s Cup dreams  The Advertiser

The Broncos sensation was keen to play through the pain barrier for either Australia or Samoa at the end-of-season tournament but Brisbane coach Wayne Bennett has delivered the bullet to Milford’s Cup hopes. Milford has played well despite a damaged shoulder he has carried for the past six weeks. His form gave Milford hope he could soldier on for another month but Bennett, also England’s coach, has made it clear his star five-eighth doesn’t have a say in the matter. If Milford played in the World Cup, he risked missing the start of the 2018 premiership at the Broncos – and Bennett was havin...

item.title: Hunters skipper Boas wins Courier-Mail Medal - The Advertiser
item.description:
Hunters skipper Boas wins Courier-Mail Medal  The Advertiser

The Hunters skipper claimed the honours at the annual QRL Awards on Wednesday night, after this year guiding his team to the top of the ladder for their first minor premiership. Boas beat out fellow contenders Matt Lodge, Brodie Croft, Krys Freeman and Michael Purcell for the medal, which is voted on by the referees. The talented five-eighth also picked up the fan-voted People’s Choice award to cap off a brilliant season. With the finals series still ahead for the Hunters, who will enjoy a bye this weekend, there are many more honours that Boas can claim. He took on the captaincy for the fi...

item.title: Meninga: You’re not welcome Matt - The Advertiser
item.description:
Meninga: You’re not welcome Matt  The Advertiser

Brisbane’s feeder club Redcliffe has made a formal submission to the NRL for Lodge to train once a week with Bennett’s Broncos squad, 16 months after his alcohol-fuelled incident led to his spending time in a US prison. The NRL integrity unit will deliver a verdict next week but it is understood the governing body will refuse to register any NRL deal for Lodge this season. Brisbane hoped Lodge would be available for selection in coming months but Meninga lashed attempts to expedite the 21-year-old’s return. Lodge is currently deregistered from the NRL but made his debut for Redcliffe last S...

item.title: Broncos refuse to release in-demand centre - The Advertiser
item.description:
Broncos refuse to release in-demand centre  The Advertiser

The 100kg Opacic impressed in his rookie season last year but has been unable to break into the NRL this season after undergoing off-season shoulder surgery. That opened the door for Cowboys import Tautau Moga, who has been a revelation for the Broncos this season at left centre. Sydney clubs are keen to secure Opacic but with Moga going to the Knights next season, Bennett insists there is a future at Red Hill for the Queensland Residents representative. LODGE MAY STAY NOW THE Matt Lodge saga has taken another twist which could see the controversial forward delay plans to quit rugby league....

item.title: Matt Lodge’s million dollar rampage bill - The Advertiser
item.description:
Matt Lodge’s million dollar rampage bill  The Advertiser

US District Court Judge Kimba Wood’s ruling against Lodge, in which he detailed the terror Lodge inflicted on German tourist Carolin Dekeyser, Manhattan couple Joseph Cartright and Ruth Fowler and their nine-year-old son, comes as the prop attempts to resurrect his NRL career. The New York law firm representing the victims vowed to recoup every cent of the judge’s order despite Lodge living in Australia. “We are looking at any and every method available to us to collect on this judgment including potentially garnishing his future wages,” Renan Varghese, a senior associate at Wigdor LLP, tol...

item.title: Woods’ warning words for NRL bad boy Lodge - The Advertiser
item.description:
Woods’ warning words for NRL bad boy Lodge  The Advertiser

Lodge is considering taking up a 2018 deal with Brisbane after launching a remarkable comeback with their feeder club Redcliffe this year. The 22-year-old ex-Tiger is one of five contenders for the second tier Queensland Cup best and fairest award after snapping a lifeline from the Dolphins in 2017. COURIER-MAIL MEDAL: Matt Lodge contender for award WAYNE PLANE: Broncos hire plane for Cowboys clash SYDNEY DOMINATION: NRL’s plan to befriend Swans Lodge has not played in the NRL for two years after the Tigers sacked him following his arrest at gunpoint for a drunken rampage in New York in Oct...

item.title: Broncos prop Lodge takes out loan to compensate victims of drunken assault - ABC News
item.description:
Broncos prop Lodge takes out loan to compensate victims of drunken assault  ABC News

Brisbane Broncos prop Matt Lodge has reached a confidential settlement compensating victims over his drunken rampage in New York in 2015. CCTV of the violent assault, during which Lodge was arrested at gunpoint, was released earlier this year. Lodge was sentenced to community service and treatment for anger and alcohol abuse. A court ordered him to pay $1.6 million to the victims, Joseph Cartright and his partner Ruth Fowler. Video: CCTV footage of Matt Lodge assaulting man in NYC (ABC News) Lodge said he has taken out a loan to pay for the compensation agreement. "In recent months I've wor...

item.title: Opinion: NRL penalty outrage is a controversy concocted by the crisis merchants - ABC News
item.description:
Opinion: NRL penalty outrage is a controversy concocted by the crisis merchants  ABC News

There are times when those who are supposed to nurture and grow the NRL instead contribute to the impression that an excellent game is in a state of perpetual crisis. The seemingly premature registration of Brisbane Broncos prop Matthew Lodge was just one recent example where the game's administration parked a fuel tanker next to a dynamite factory. And then there are those occasions when the NRL enacts the sensible policy needed to improve the game, yet still somehow finds itself in the middle of a controversy concocted by the crisis merchants determined to find gloom and doom in every sit...

item.title: NRL will tear up Matt Lodge's contract if he doesn't start paying compensation - ABC News
item.description:
NRL will tear up Matt Lodge's contract if he doesn't start paying compensation  ABC News

The NRL has ordered Brisbane Broncos player Matt Lodge to begin paying back the victims of his New York City assault or risk having his contract terminated. Lodge forced himself into a Manhattan apartment in October 2015 and assaulted Joseph Cartright while his wife Ruth Fowler and their nine-year-old child hid. Lodge said in a television interview two weeks ago that he was on sleeping pills and had drunk alcohol at the time, and he apologised to the victims. Photo: Matt Lodge needs to start paying his victims or he will have his contract terminated. (AAP: Dave Hunt) But Lodge still owes mo...

item.title: Broncos sponsor says Lodge's behaviour 'completely unacceptable' - ABC News
item.description:
Broncos sponsor says Lodge's behaviour 'completely unacceptable'  ABC News

Brisbane Broncos' principal sponsor, NRMA Insurance, has condemned the past behaviour of forward Matthew Lodge, describing it as "completely unacceptable". In a post on social media, the company says it is "very concerned" about the impact of Lodge's violence on victims and families. "Matthew Lodge's past behaviour is completely unacceptable and we are very concerned by the long-term impact this has had on his victims and their families," the tweet said. Lodge is yet to pay for compensation to the victims of his 2015 drunken rampage in New York, and details have surfaced in recent days abou...

item.title: Matthew Lodge facing NRL axe if he does not pay his victims - The Guardian
item.description:
Matthew Lodge facing NRL axe if he does not pay his victims  The Guardian

The NRL has ordered Matt Lodge to pay back the victims of his New York rampage and threatened to sever his contract unless he comes up with a payment plan. As debate continues to swirl about the controversial Brisbane prop’s participation in the game, the NRL have put their foot down and ordered him to begin paying back the $1.6m ordered following a US civil lawsuit. Related: Greg Inglis racial abuse claim: NRL to 'throw book' at culprit Ruth Fowler and Joseph Cartright said they had never received an apology from Lodge and he had never attempted to begin paying back what was owed to them –...

item.title: Stop-start NRL games 'can't be great viewing', says Cameron Smith - The Guardian
item.description:
Stop-start NRL games 'can't be great viewing', says Cameron Smith  The Guardian

Cameron Smith says the referee crackdown on off-side is making poor viewing for NRL fans but the Melbourne Storm skipper believes the issue lies with players rather than the referees. Related: Competition for the ball is back and the NRL is the better for it | Matt Cleary There were 20 penalties in the Storm’s 30-14 win over North Queensland on Thursday night, following on from 26 conceded in Melbourne’s round two loss to Wests Tigers. The Tigers were accused of deliberately giving away penalties on their own line in a bid to reset their defence. In the AAMI Park match 10 of the penalties w...

item.title: Analysis: Slater a rare one-club star in an era of musical chairs - ABC News
item.description:
Analysis: Slater a rare one-club star in an era of musical chairs  ABC News

That Billy Slater will play his 300th NRL game on Saturday night is cause for warm celebration, surely even by those who still haven't forgiven Melbourne Storm for its greatest sin — being better than everyone else. That Slater had to overcome considerable odds in recent seasons to reach this significant milestone has added an endearing element to a career that seemed the fulfilment of incredible natural gifts; at least to those not familiar with his enormous work ethic. Slater's march to 300 was halted by a shoulder so mangled he once feared he would not be able to pick up his two children...

item.title: 'Fans expect better': Cricket Australia knows player behaviour has failed the pub test - ABC News
item.description:
'Fans expect better': Cricket Australia knows player behaviour has failed the pub test  ABC News

Bitter sniping on the field, stairwell threats off it; barrel-chested send-offs and, most pitifully, South African officials aiding and abetting the misogynistic "humour" of some low-life spectators. Only those pretending to live in some sort of reality-proof bubble could flippantly discard the acrimonious events that have surrounded the first two Tests in South Africa and expect us to concentrate only on the cricket itself, even as AB de Villiers caressed another sublime cover drive. Sadly, the conflict has not been removed from the contest but ingrained in it. First in the verbal warfare ...

item.title: Lodge's NRL return questioned again as he makes Broncos debut - ABC News
item.description:
Lodge's NRL return questioned again as he makes Broncos debut  ABC News

Matt Lodge made his return to the NRL in Brisbane's 34-12 loss to St George Illawarra in the 2018 season opener, but his place in the game was met by renewed questioning. Lodge had not played in the NRL since his Wests Tigers contract was terminated in 2015 as a result of his violent home invasion in New York the same year. External Link: Grandstand discuss the Matthew Lodge controversy He was arrested at gunpoint by New York police and avoided a jail term in the United States with a plea deal but was given a $1.5 million damages bill, of which the victims of his attack claim they have not ...

item.title: Matthew Lodge says he was 'reckless' with prescription drugs at time of attack - The Guardian
item.description:
Matthew Lodge says he was 'reckless' with prescription drugs at time of attack  The Guardian

Matt Lodge says tests after his arrest in New York showed he had mixed a “lethal dose” of sleeping pills with alcohol but the 22-year-old said he could not remember the attack after waking up handcuffed to a bed. Lodge revealed his battle with prescription drugs while giving his first insight into the 2015 incident after Brisbane received criticism for throwing the prop an NRL lifeline this year. Related: The case of Matthew Lodge: when a line in the sand must be drawn | Nick Tedeschi The backlash over his return threatens to overshadow the Broncos’ season opener against St George Illawarra...

item.title: NRL should dock Lodge's wages to compensate victims, Daley says - ABC News
item.description:
NRL should dock Lodge's wages to compensate victims, Daley says  ABC News

Former NSW Origin coach Laurie Daley says Matt Lodge's pay should be docked to help pay his victims' compensation. Daley said there is no doubt the Brisbane player, who makes his NRL return on Thursday, is trying to atone for his New York rampage two years ago. But steps needed to be made to ensure his victims, which include a nine-year-old boy, receive the $1.5 million in damages a US court ordered the 22-year-old pay. The victims say they have not received any payment and claim Lodge is trying to avoid justice by returning to the NRL. "The NRL should lead the way. They need to garnish his...
